name: No More Room in Hell
developer: No More Room in Hell Team
description: "When there's no more room in hell, the dead will walk the earth."A tribute to the highly acclaimed film series in which the above quote originated from, No More Room in Hell (PC Gamer's Mod of the Year 2011, ModDB's Editor Choice Multiplayer Mod of the Year 2011), is a co-operative realistic first person survival horror...
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows® Vista or better Processor: Dual core 2.4 GHz processor or better  Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Radeon HD 5000 Series or nVidia GeForce 200 series or better DirectX®: 9.0c Hard Drive: 10 GB HD space Sound: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound Other Requirements: Mouse, Keyboard, Broadband Internet connection with at least 5Mbps up/down

reviews.review_text: Friend got infected and we had no pills so I shot him in the face 10/10

Zephyr, survival.  I join a server just in time for the mad dash for items of value at the start, managing to pick myself up an SA Vz.58 assault rifle with twenty rounds of ammunition.  I look around me, see others with better weapons, and others that could only grab a pipe or knife, consider myself lucky.  'Hey man, can I have that ak?' I turn around, jason bateman points a 22 pistol at my head. His name-tag reads 'darkman'.  'No, you got a gun already.'   'nah man it's a 22- it's ♥♥♥♥.'  'You can't have the ak.'  '♥♥♥♥ you.'  Necessary dialogue is exchanged in the starting area, people form alliances, grudges, allies and enemies. I find myself pairing up with a guy called 'shitler', who picked up a sledgehammer and a few medical items.  We then head down the lower extremeties of the building, going by a staircase until we finally reach the first door. Moans can be heard on the other side, along with the unmistakable slapping of feet on the ground.  'Hey heshy, you go first, you got the ak.' someone says.  I oblige, pushing open the door and entering partly.  It's a medium sized car park area, cars srewn about, left like ghosts of some ancient civilisation, and plenty of zombies too, slower ones, walking around aimlessly, and perhaps three runners at the back.  I focus my attention on the immediate danger, centre the iron sights and take aim on the closest runner, about four metres away, making a beeline straight for me.  I stay trained on it's head, waiting for the right moment, ready to pull the trigger before I hear the door behind me creak shut.  'Shoulda given the ak.' It's darkman, decided to trap me in here in hopes of satisfying some mis-guided want for revenge.  I pull the trigger, or rather hit mouse1, but the sound of the door put me out of focus and jutted my aim off to the left.  The bullet whizzes through the air, and chunks of rock and dust particles fly out from the wall behind the runner.  Too late.  The runner is upon me now, and my only reaction is to frantically hit 'v' as fast as I can. I push him away with the side of my rifle, stumbling it.  This gives me enough time to point my gun in its general direction, wildly firing into the oncoming swarm of zombies.  I waste about twelve rounds before two runners and a walker goes down.  Eight rounds left. Conservation top priority.  I take the time to glance at chat. It's wild. People are arguing. Words whizz by like matrix graphics, and I'm just glad no-one's using voice com.  At this, I hold 'shift' and book it to the corner of the room; there's a keypad and a locked wire-mesh door that leads into a small office.  someone says '6064' In chat.  I punch it in, no response. turn around, gun aimed, fire three more shots. This time more accurate, on point. manage four kills. The door I came out from is frantically juttering open and shut, whilst people battle to open it or close it.  '7175' Someone else says.  I punch it in, key pad flashed green and the door opens.  Inside, a shelf filled with boxes, a computer desk with a handgun resting on it.  I pick it up. 45 cal.  there's also a button in the corner- I press it, shutters are lowered and the street outside is now available to us.  10/10 would be a reluctant hero again.

This is a free zombie game that runs better than other games in the genre and gets better dev support too. I've played this game since it came out and I have to say I'm really impressed with it. Yes there are some bugs but they're rarely game breaking and usually not too much of a problem. The weapons are fun to use and actually require a decent amount of skill (what with the lack of crosshairs, limited amount of ammo, and wide variety of melee weapons). The zombies work well too, crawlers, walkers, runners, and kids all provide a bit of variety and can spice up the game/scare the hell out of you. All in all it's a very enjoyable game and I hope the developers continue to work on it and the community continues to support it.   TIPS:  1. Use your sights. 2. If you melee, PUSH the zombies away after every swing.  3. Communicate, even without a mic it's really useful. 4. Don't waste ammo. (Especially on the first few rounds of a survival map) 5. Don't hoard ammo you aren't using, chances are someone else needs it. 6. Don't attack the same zombie at once. It wastes ammo or it clusters people up so they miss their swings.  7. Use the flare gun to call in supplies (Survival). 8. Conserve your energy, if you're out of breath, back away for a few seconds. 9. If you're infected call it out. If there are no pills at all, shoot yourself. 10. Have fun and send the zombies back to hell!
My friend asked a guy if he had pills and he said no. My friend shot him, he did have pills afterall.  I shot my friend because I was infected too.  10/10 I got the pills.
No More Room In Hell Review

This game honestly surprised me. I, myself am not a free to play type of person, in fact I think most, 90% of free-to-plays are absolute ♥♥♥♥ designed to try and suck money out of me. Not this one, this is up there in some of my favorite f2p games, and yes, I'll admit, this game isn't without it's flaws but it's one game that has semi changed my opinion on Free-to-Play.  Let me start with the good, for a Source Game, an engine of 10+ years, this game looks great, apart from zombies looking like they came out of a low budget B-movie horror flick and the no texture bug which appears on the eyes of some characters (I laugh this one away and think of it as an intended bug for immersion) it's pretty good. In some of the settings, they've hidden away a few graphics options that are experimental such as Lens Flare but is worth enabling. NMRiH really immerses you into the thought that you are a survivor and must get through this with it's graphics, the vanilla maps have been designed very well for immersion in mind. The lighting creates this bleak atmosphere that not many other Survival Horror games create, Left 4 Dead (yes the lighting is still very good but not like NMRiH in any way), DayZ to name a few. It keeps to a certain design framework that really wants to keep you immersed and constantly on alert as every dark corner there may be undead lurking. It emphases the use of Flashlights which are possibly one of the best utilities seen in any game I've played.   Away from the Atmosphere and the Graphics, the combat matches this very well. Ammo for guns is rare, something that really does fit a realistic scenario of such a thing happening and it requires you to make every shot count. Melee combat is interesting too as it has an invisible stamina meter, requiring you to time your swings and make every bit of your energy count. Weapons like Sledgehammers, FUBARs and Shovels drain it more but with the chance of one hit kills and possibly killing multiple zombies, other weapons, like Machetes, Hatchets, don't do as much damage but use little stamina, keeping you on in the fight. That moves me onto the next great thing about this game, the variety of weapons and how they each have a destined purpose. Pistols are great, they're all different and have their own specialties. The Beretta M9 is a 9mm Pistol and the ammo is rather common, it's a 2 hit kill and my favorite pistol due to the sights being better than that of the other 9mm, the Glock 17 which has a larger ammo capacity but worse sights, again in my opinion. Weapons are so varied with it's uses that they're all worth trying to match your game style. Would you like to pick up the M16 or would you rather take a more recyclable approach with a Compound Bow.   Other mechanics in this game away from combat is the ability to become infected and must be warded off with Phlanx Pills (a reference to one of my all time favorite novels by Max Brookes - World War Z) or Gene Therapy, which completely cures you. You can barricade entrances with a claw hammer and some wooden planks, end your teammates (or yourself) to rid them of the burden that may encumber you later in game and more. You can even change your character and his voice. I'm not going to go much more in detail with the other mechanics, these are the best ones, so you'll have to encounter some of the other ones in game yourself.   This section is dedicated to the AI and the Level Design. I'm not gonna lie, the AI really needs patching up, it's ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and needs some work. However it's predictable and unpredictable nature (yes the AI is both) keep you on constant alert. An infected teammate has gone down, where the hell could he be? Well he's glitched out running in circles around where you turned. That's one major issue with the game. Away from AI, the levels are really good. If you're playing slowly, they can sometimes take up to 30 minutes to complete and can be quite the blast if you're last man standing. The maps, each and every one of them are unique and require different objectives and many of them have different paths for different playthroughs. Not major though, but something to change up gameplay each time.   All in all NMRiH is a great F2P game, a slightly cancerous community as I've encountered many annoying little kids in my mere 30 hours of gameplay but overall pretty damn good. 8/10.

This was a game mod for HL2 and it took years to make into a standalone game.  This game is a cooperative zombie outbreak survival game. The game is very unique and not like other zombie games. Great Maps and AI and you really better count on your team.  The game is 8 Player Co-op and focuses on survival and the atmosphere, you have to collect your weapons and be aware of Ammo and meelee weapons. The game gives a more relestic approach over games like Dead Rising and L4D.  If you like games related to zombies that are unique at the same time, I would recommend this. And it's FREE! Really free, no premium, Pay 2 win, ads etc. I would give this 10/10 by Free game standards, download it now.

This game is seriously sick, and it's free what have you got to lose? besides hours of your life to murdering hoards of zombies!  We NEED more people playing this, now.  But seriously, this is a really good game. The community is usually very good, met some great people on it. The game it's self is just alot of fun to play with the seemingly endless amount of maps like camp blood (the camp from the friday the 13th movies) or the Night of the Living Dead farm house just to name to cool ones. You can do objective style games like left 4 dead, or you can do pure survival (my favourite). The servers are great, you can really test your self with a straight up survival feel, finding guns and weapons on the floors and dividing ammo like a team. Or you can just spawn guns and unlimited ammo, hell go god mode if you want the wide range of servers allow it all! The graphics though a little on the plain side are much better than other free games imo, i really prefer playing this over other mainstream zombie games because it just feels more real, the lighting and atmosphere is alot darker and creepy and the guns and melee and other items are just nice to use, especially with the ability to aim down sights.  I recommend this a thousand times over and cant wait for NMRIH 2! This is a game worth paying for.

One of the most in-depth, immersive and haunting cooperative experiences ever written. Powered by the venerable Source Engine, the Zombie Apocalypse truly comes alive in No More Room in Hell; an eerie but spellbinding sountrack, incredible attention to detail in all areas, unparelled depth to gameplay and seemingly endless hordes which your few resources or weapons won't permanently end. This is the Apocalypse done right, something that should be cherished by lovers of the cooperative genre. Remember to bring your friends......and be prepared to make some hard calls in the name of survival.

A real zombie game! NOT LIKE DAYZ! i mean dayz is now kill humans not zombies simulator, like if zombies are in the background.. Now back to NMRIH. This game features no respawning except if they reached a checkpoint. So stay alive. Also no ammo meter, health bar and weapons need to be searched for as well as ammo is scarce. Stay alive survivors. Oh and this IS FREE! No microtransactions.

Once you enter the game the fun and adventure qualities will immediately help you enjoy the game. Although you may think all is lost once you and your team is almost destroyed by the zombies, you'll notice the need to bash their head in with the Fubar, reunite, dont give up, and to make it to the end.  Finishing a map feels so good. Knowing that you survived an apocalypse, did it with a few people, and got extracted by the military is amazing isn't it? A game this amazing and smartly made is just cool. I would really play it.  Overall score for me:  9.5/10 Fun Factor: Good for halloween gaming and could really make you happy. Lagginess Level: Even low-spec computers can handle this game really easily. Values to be distributed: Strength, Determination, and Teamwork  2 Words to describe this game: Pure Fun.

No More Room in Hell is a pretty fun game but also really hard to learn and master. It's quite refreshing to play a game where getting bitten is dangerous. Fans of the George A Romero movies like Night of The Living Dead are gonna love this game cause it's based on those movies.

The world needs more games like this. The graphics are not too impressive, but that can be a good thing, because it means I can run it on a fairly old laptop. It's a fun game and that's what matters. Best of all, it's free so there are always people online.

The closest thing you are going to get to realism (ignoring the, yaknow, zombies). Slower than most games, but more tense. You aren't some 'special' individual with immunity. Just some people in some pretty bleak circumstances. Not every headshot is a guarenteed kill with every gun. Half the pistols have trouble getting instant kills, as of their lower caliber. Not every bite results in infection, the unfortunate zombie swipe might cut deep, and you'll need some good doctor's work, or just some bandages you found on the ground. Your fellow man can screw you over as good as the average horde of zombies(at times they use said horde). Some guy can take all the ammo, and another all the guns. Neither will give in, and you either go along until one of them dies, of kill one now. Killing one now removes the risk of gear loss, but can lead to the collapse of the group. The only thing I can think of to complain about is when a teammate is infected and a teammate kills them, followed by the dilligent teammate getting kicked for TK by vote.

Another chilling example of cinematic excellence by acclaimed director Lars von Tier, No More Room in Harlem is a gripping coming-of-age biopic about the Troubles of growing up in the shadow of dope slingers and gang bangers in the impoverished half of the Big Apple. Starring Jayden Smith as Te'Niel Dadaist, a street wise hood orphan who grew up on the wrong side of the tracks, and ‎Quvenzhané Wallis as the happy-go-lucky Alicia Wunduhlund whose only got 5 months to live. Also starring Anthony Mackie as Big Wood, this cultural phenonemon is already sweeping the globe and bringing those who have lived through the Troubles standing up and proclaiming proudly, with their hearts full and their eyes damp, 'I was there.'  TL;DR 10/10 It's free, it plays pretty well, and it ISN'T CONTAGION.

Well, what can I say?  As a surge of 'free-to-play-and-pay''s hit the market, it is incredibly refreshing to see a title unburdened with any fees or restrictions that is so fun. This game means so much to me that I am personally paying more so that I can feel as though I am helping the developers (Canadians (I think?) that seem so helpful on forums, by the way~) I am really at a loss to what I should say, for experiencing the game yourself will be all the more useful; my words can't do it justice.  Alas, I do realise that a review should be more than ♥♥♥-kissing. So, let's turn on the jazz, grab some Monster, and discuss No More Room in Hell a little more.  This game is not perfect; this should be an expectation void from every game, though. While I, personally, find this slow, co-op-orientated zombie-smashing game fun, I do concede that this would seem strange (if not plain unenjoyable) to someone more inclined to a game like Left 4 Dead. NMRiH is, by no means, one were ammo can be squandered; to make this fact apparent, join any nightmare server running survival maps. You must think about the shots you make, your stamina, your health and the health of those around you, what's behind you... In essense, I feel as though you will enjoy this sort of atmosphere if you like long-term goals, tense points and the relief that will follow. An added bonus to this slower, staggered gameplay as opposed to L4D is that the weapons mean a lot more. A shotgun decimating 2 zombies in a row feels impactful, meaningful; not many games can boast this feeling, at least to me.  There are more superficial complaints that I have heard (third-person animations, voice acting, etc.) that I really do not feel like arguing over. My philosophy on this matter is that if you enjoy the core gameplay of a title, you can look over a lot. Through the updates still applied to this game, I can only expect that NMRiH will improve.   Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go hit some of these zed sods with a shovel. Bye!

No More Room in Hell is a completely free co-operative first person survival horror game. The game includes:  - Co-op play with up to 8 players. - Dynamic Objective Maps: Each time you play a map, objectives could be placed in different locations. - Realism: No crosshairs and no HUD. - Infection: When you get bitten by a zombie, it is possible becoming one of them. You only have a certain amount of time to heal or you will die and come back as a zombie. - 2 game modes: Survive several waves of zombies or do objective based maps. - A lot of maps. - Many different weapons.  No More Room in Hell is nearly impossible to win alone, cooperation is the key to win. Graphics are average and not up to date anymore. The sound fits to the game. There could be more sound effects but overall it is ok. One of the best free games on Steam, especially when playing with friends. If you search for a zombie game - Try it!  Sounds 7/10 Graphics 5/10 Gameplay 7/10 Atmosphere 8/10

First off let's get one thing clear. I am a lifelong zombie afficionado. I love zombie related games, movies, and all things of the walking corpse variety. That being said there is only one thing I have to say about this game. This game is a zombie lover's dream. It's pretty spot on for the look and feel of the things that made the genre great. There's that feeling of isolation, having to counting your ammo, being forced to rely on people you may not like in order to survive, and of course hordes of the walking dead coming at you at all times. In my opinion it is a game made for fans of the genre by the fans of the genre. Although anyone who enjoys a good game should most assuredly give it a shot as well. There are a few things that need a little more polish but the developers of this game are active in it's community and seem to be always continuing to make this game even better. Even if you don't like the counting the ammo aspect of this game there are more than enough private servers on this game with infinite ammo enabled to get rid of that problem if it isn't your thing (I for one enjoy having to count my shells from time to time because of the challenge it represents). I love how each weapon has it's own distinctive feel (even if it's only a subtle difference) and the little details on each map that displays how much time was put into this game to make it awesome. There's nothing bad I can find to say about this game other than the movement of the players is interesting to watch to say the least.

A mod I've watched develop for nearly a decade, No More Room in Hell is possibly the last hurrah we'll see from the Half-Life 2 modding community. Teamwork is as valuable as ammunition, and with the difficulty of many of the maps you're going to need friends at your side. It's not free-to-play, it's just plain free. So grab a few buddies and check it out; this is some of the best gaming you've seen on the source engine since Half-Life 2 itself.

A great game! Endless fun and chaos! Make sure you have a good and solid team with you!    - No HUD adds to the realism and challenge, ammo checks are done manually by holding 'R'    - A wide variety of weapons: Melee range --> light > medium > heavy (choose what suits your game style and the situation best.    + Firearms: Anything from handguns, semi-autos, shot guns, rifles and even a bow and arrow.    - Explosives... 'nuff said.    - Speed: Although even your normal walking speed is faster than most of the un-dead (sans 'Runners') don't grow complacent, you can still be surrounded on all sides or cut off from your team.    - The 'V' button is your friend.    - Communicate by pressing 'Y' to chat or holding down the wheel of your mouse to use voice. Communication is vital for survival.   As mentioned earlier, a good team is vital. A key to a good team (other than not dying 3 seconds after spawning in every time) is communication.  Since there is no HUD you have to ask other players to relay to you what color your name is. GREEN = Full Health, ORANGE = Medium or Bleeding, RED = you're in the danger zone (DAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAANGER ZOOOOOOOOOOOOONE).  Another way to tell what your health status is is by simply looking at your screen and listening to what your character is saying. If your screen is flashing red, then it means you are bleeding and the color on your screen starts fading unless you get a Bandage or First Aid Kit.  It's handy to have a team mate yelling at you to 'TAKE THE FU**ING FIRST AID KIT' or when you're infected and they give you a gun to kill yourself with. THAT is when you know they care and an indication you have a team-mate for life (or for as long as you live, which isn't really that long realistically)  PRO TIP: When melee-ing, don't stand too close to the zombie and ALWAYS PRESS 'V' RIGHT AFTER A MELEE ATTACK.  Trust me, it will save your life.  11/10 would recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

For those of you who have played L4D2, you will most likely have come across the realism mode. The difference between realism mode and the normal co-op mode in L4D2 is that in realism mode you cannot see the silhouette of your teammates, items, and you cannot come out of the closet (respawn) when you are dead. Most players take the realism mode as an additional challenge as it adds a certain amount of difficulty to the already challenging expert co-op mode. The aim of L4D2's realism mode is to make the game real so that you can have a taste of reality in L4D2. It works well, though when L4D2's realism mode is pitted against No More Room in Hell, L4D2 looses out in almost all aspects of realism.   The first thing you need to know about No More Room in Hell (NMRH from here on) is that it is a Mod for Source games (Half-Life 2, Portal 2, Counter-Strike: Source, Left 4 Dead 2 ... etc). Meaning, you will need at least one copy of such games installed before you can play it. The game (or mod) itself is free, so don't worry about that. Since NMRH is a mod, you can basically expect graphics and controls very similar to that of Half-Life 2 and other games based upon the source engine. There really isn't anything spectacular about the graphics and controls, so I'll leave it for you t decide for yourself.  After installing NMRH (and maybe a source based game if you have not already done so), you are ready for your first game. You go in, choose a server in a very Counter-Strike manner (opening a server list and clicking on a server you like, which most likely will be a server with the lowest ping and an empty slot), and you wait for your game to load. You will be curious how the game will be. Finally, after somewhat less than a minute (on my gear), the game is finally loaded and ...  ... four empty walls.  Well, to be fair, there are some run down furnitures and the environment is decorated with cracks and dust, but the point is, where are the HUDs (Head-Up Display)? In a typical first-person shooter, there will be numbers representing your health and the amount of ammunition you are currently holding on to. Alright, I was not holding a gun so maybe I don't get to see any numbers representing any bullets. Fine. But what about my health? What I have found out, later on, is that there are no in-game HUDs that represents your health value. On the other hand, health is represented by the colour saturation of your in game graphics - the lower the value of your health is, the lower the colour saturation will be and your screen will look pretty much grayscale-ish before you fall on your face. Also, your screen will be highlighted red if you are injured or infected (the highlight for each condition differs from each other).   After walking around for a bit, triggering green silhouettes whenever you look at items lying around (or red when your backpack is full) and picking them up, I soon come to realize that there actually are HUDs in the game. One is your Fallout-3-like compass (remember, you don't have a map). Another is the item and ammo screen (1, 2). The third are the instructions given, which will pop out in the middle of your screen when you've triggered them. The last one is the number of ammunition you have (at least you get to see how much ammo you have left, phew!).  Speaking about guns, the game tries to make its item system as realistic as possible, just like many other aspects of the game. In order to do so, the game uses something similar to a 'weight system' for its item system (something like Killing Floor, I guess). Larger, heavier and, more importantly, higher dammage items takes up more weight, while lighter, weaker and, generally speaking, more useless items take up less weight. For example, a fire axe, something that can split the skull of the zombies with one charged swing, will take up more space then a torchligh, a little black stick which you can use to shine the places on the zombies where sun don't shine or simply whack them so that they can whack you back and infect you. The same applies for large weapons, such as M4A1, which is definitely much heavier than little hammers used for nailing boards (where do the nails come from, I always wonder). Ammunitions take up space too, so becareful not to take up too many unwanted ammunition types.   What's next after picking up your utensils ... I mean, weapons? Your dinner... I mean, enemy. There are 2 distinctive types of zombies in general: slow and fast. Most of them are slow ones, so you can pretty much blow their head up with a well aimed melee strike with a fire axe or sledge hammer. Melee is always recommended, especially when you have quite a number of temmates to back you up, as ammunitions are highly scarce in game (reality, duh!). Of course, you better not get hit by your enemy. Even if you do get hit by an enemy, which will happen at least once in every game, you better not get infested, as you will definitely and inevitably die, with your corpse rising as a fast zombie, running towards your living comrades and trying to kill them. Well, its actually kind of nice watching your comrades trying to fight your zombified self. Maybe it's because you get kind of envy of them for being alive, and they can't hear you on chat once you are dead.   For the general picture, this game is bleak, barren and aims to be highly realistic. As a matter of fact, it is actually succeeding in terms of realism because when I first played it, the realism bores me to tears (I was playing alone). Whacking zombie after zombie, trying to meet the objectives which is to whack more zombies is not as entertaining as it seems, so much so that I initially have removed the game from my list (it's free anyway). But then, a Korean friend of mine started playing, so I reinstalled the game and picked it up again and, to be honest, playing NMRH with friends has a type of peculiar yet interesting taste to it. It is actually fun when you sit back, strode through the zombified garden with your friend, help each other out when in need, laugh at your peers that fell in battle, and get laughed at when your zombified peers start tearing you apart. Yeah, that is how some of my nights are spent.  NMRH is an interesting game when you play with a bunch of people. It will amaze you how barren and inconvenient reality is, and how a tiny little mistake can amplify and manifest into a giant globe of chaos. It's not a complicated game, so anyone can go in, shoot a few, get killed, and watch your zombified self run wild and get killed again. It's free anyway. Still, be warned that you should have your mobile phone or tablet or a book with you, as you might have to wait for a long long while before you can play again once you are dead. Reality, yeah?  P.S. [Easter Egg] If you ever play the map Chinatown, look out for a blue sign saying '按摩你的屁股'. It literally means 'massage your backside'.

The amount of fun to be had in No More Room in Hell is purely based on who you play with.  Yes, this may also be true for the majority of online multiplayer games, but it is especially true when it comes to cooperative games. No More Room in Hell is less a game, and much more a social experience. If the social mechanics are removed, or non-existent, there is zero to no enjoyment to be found here. Unfortunately, many times you join a server, no one is communicating by voice. Not even via the text chat. This limits the overall gaming experience of No More Room in Hell to a valueless venture into a boring and uneventful zombie apocalypse scenario. Other times, you will join a server and be in the presence of voice chatters who are playing very loud music or TV in the background, or people who are only interested in communicating and playing with their friend, in their common language that no one else understands, while ignoring everything and everyone else. Then there are the people you will find that aren't actually playing the game for its purpose at all. Luckily, there are the rare times that you join a server and most, if not all people involved are communicating well, attempting to succeed in the game's objectives, and being helpful in the survival of all participants. People from all over the world, working together. Sadly, these perfect moments in No More Room in Hell are few and far between.  The Source Engine server browser has its many known faults, and blacklisting servers often does not work. There are many servers out there that ignore the game's purpose in every way possible. These servers have taken No More Room in Hell and spoiled every objective, every gameplay mechanic, and have made it their own worthless variation of it. If you join them, you will find that the standard game's survival and cooperative mechanics have been replaced with unlimited ammo, a free and unlimited guns menu, and other server-side changes, such as automatic respawns and other options that are there to simply ruin the standard game. Those servers are not playing the game created by the developers.  No More Room in Hell has a surprising amount of content for being a completely free game, and the developers seem to be devoted to its continued success with frequent and sizable patches and updates. They are often responding to posts in the Steam forums, and sometimes can even be found playing the game and answering questions using the voice chat. The game may be quite unpolished in certain areas and low budget, but for it being 100% free, it's still impressive at some level. Hit detection when it comes to melee combat is definitely an area that takes some getting used to, but once you learn how to handle the various melee weapons, it does become satisfying to down zombies with one hit. The firearms also feel agreeable, and collecting then exchanging ammo with the other survivors can be very fun. At the moment, there are two game modes. One is objective based, while the other is centered on defense of designated areas and wave survival. Both are extremely enjoyable if played with the right group of people.   Playing the server lottery in a cooperative game can be disappointing, but if you are lucky enough to be able to find a server with people playing the game to its full potential, No More Room in Hell can be a lot of fun. It's just a shame that most people aren't playing the game that No More Room in Hell is intended to be.  No More Room in Hell is good.

No More Room is a survival horror FPS zombie game. Weapons are limited, so survivors have to make the best of them. Also, there are two types of gamemodes. In the survival gamemode, there are zones to maintain. The zones can be defended if the imposing zombies are killed, however if the zones fall, the survivors lose. In the objective gamemode, survivors complete a series of tasks, so that they can be safely extracted. If the survivors die or take too long to reach the point of extraction, they lose. A player can run a LAN server that any other local player can join, but assuming there aren't any local players in the area, it could be played as a singleplayer server. If a player wants to play with other specific players, they could run a multiplayer server. A multiplayer server would show up on the Internet, so any other player could join, but servers can be protected by passwords. If a player runs their own server, their latency will be pretty low, but the latency of players connecting to their server will be significantly higher. Running a LAN server is ideal for achievements, many of which can be obtained by getting a certain number of kills with the different weapons in the game. No More Room in Hell is free and players can even create their own maps. Good game, 9/10.

No More Room in Hell is an amazing Co-Op Survival game with a lot of emphasis on the Co-Op. If you don't work together, you'll fall victim to the hordes. This game has tons of polish, and is very well supported by the developers. It's basically what I describe as a realistic Left 4 Dead. It's the same basic concept, a team of players have to work together to complete objectives while avoiding hordes of zombies. Notice how I said AVOID. More often than not, killing zombies is simply not worth your time unless it's absolutely necessary. Zombies are slow for the most part, except for some runners and the occasional child, but they are also quite resilient. You are not very powerful and tire quickly, so it takes some thought before taking on a horde. You can also take bleeding damage, and even get infected, which makes fighting even more dangerous. Basically, cooperation is the name of the game, and this is an experience not to be missed for zombie fans and co-op fans alike.

The Negative but Recommended review.  NMRiH is an excellent mod. The fact that it is free just sweetens the deal. But im not here to tell you what is good about it. Now don't get me wrong, I DO recommend this game, but I am writing this as a review to things you will probably find wrong with it.    So here we go: -Its hard to find a server that is the default gametype. Yes you can type Classic into the filter but even then a lot of servers you will join will have changes made to them. -Like most Source games, you cannot just create a session for you and a friend to hop onto. Which means you have to join a server or create one. So don't expect to just play with a friend or two without randoms joining.  -With that being said, randoms cause a lot of lag. This already difficult game, (if playing on 'Classic') now becomes 100x harder with lag due to zombies killing you in 3 - 8 hits as you are depending on your melee weapon. (Tip: Melee then Shove, Melee then Shove) -Maps do seem to bug out somtimes, doors will not open, getting stuck inside objects, etc. It doesn't happen often, but it's general Source bugs. -Small learning curve. Expect to die a lot the first few times you play. But it does become extremely addictive. -It could just be me, because im not a big fan of Survival/Wave type games. But the Survival Maps quickly become boring and seem a bit too easy compared to Objective/Linear maps. - Only 3 types of zombies that arent all that different in terms of combat. Slow walkers, Runner and Children. (Children being just a smaller and weaker Runner) This isn't really a problem, due to the fact none of the zombies are that hard to kill. Its more a numbers game.  Anyways, like I said I DO recommend this game because it is fun, it is addicting, it is hard. But these problems were the largest that popped out at me. My friends had the same gripes aswell. Add in easy session creation so you can just play with friends on the fly without joining/creating a server and I would pay $30+ for this game.

overall this is a positive experience but not by much. i'd rate it a strong 6. overall enjoyable, especially since it's free, but it comes with shortcomings. It's not good enough to spend money on. polish is something it needs. all games should penalize you for not playing correctly or just sucking, but it's a whole other thing when the game penalizes you soley on luck. the hit boxes need to be fixed is my main con, yet that's just the tip of the iceberg. what i'm talking about though is when i'm using a melee weapon and I have a runner coming at me, I power swing, hit it in the head, dead one hit, all good all fine. then another comes up to be i do the same exact thing and for whatever reason the hit mark gets in the chest, it beats me silly and I die. this is a constant thing, and something i can stand solely on the game being free. also mission markers will dissapear when in survival mode, friends will die and their names will float around, sometimes crawling zeds will stand up (especially when moving into an obstacle). items will get stuck and dissallow you from using them. Most of these are minor flaws, but going back I can tell you another MAJOR flaw and that's with game design: there's no respawning, WHICH IS FINE, or WOULD be fine if they game clearer ♥♥♥♥ing objectives. they too little often highlight the objective which makes it a pain for anybody who watching who's already died, it's not on the surviving player, it's not on the people who want to play the game, it's on the sheer lack of information the game gives the survivors to progress which in turn draws out a match much much longer than wanted. especially when considering the maps change so infrequently which NOBODY seems to like. So overall: 6/10

Here are some pros and cons for the game:  PROS: Free to play;  Cool community, large and active (yes, there are SOME annoying kids like there are in every other online game);  Nice graphics, maps and textures for a free-to-play game;  Good multiplayer;  Depressing soundtrack and ambience;  CONS: Some bugs;  The character walking animation in 3rd person is weird, it´s like all characters are walking with something up their a**;  CAN get kind of boring;  There hasn´t been an update for almost a year (which could mean they could be working on something pretty damn cool, or maybe not).  Hope this helped for anyone new to it!

'No More Room In Hell' or 'NMRIH' as my friends and I know it, is an addictive action based Zombie Game. The Aim of the game is to survive as long as possibe agains the constant horde of Zombies. The game is in pretty early stages (Or is when I am writing this) and has several bugs. But it never fails to deliver a fun and scary experience.  The best part of the game is it's complete differences to most games like 'Left 4 Dead' and 'Dead Rising'. Sure you are in a First person perspective like in (L4D) but you havent got the equipment all set out at the start which in turn means you have to look for any around the area/map.  TIP FROM ME: Go for the Pistol and Flashlight along with a Mele Weapon of one's choice.  There is also the realism of the game. If you are bitten in (L4D) Cool 1% is taken off and you can heal in no time. But in 'NMRIH' there is the Infection and Bleeding System. Very Rarely will you bleed to death. Almost 98% of the time you will be Infected and will require pills (Ha Louis) to get better, But it's not a one time thing. After a while the pills effects wear off and the Infection takes hold again, So if you are out there in the world alone of with friends, it is best to carry a plenteful supply of pills.  Another cool thing is the addition of different types of Zombies. Sure there was many in (L4D) but in 'NMIRH' there are: Runners Children Zombies Walkers  I never thought I would be so scared of a child in my life. Anyway enough rambling from me! I have the elignment of Exedor to see.   Have fun playing!  HowardChap (AKA: The Doctor)

I know there are several games like this, but in my opinion. It seems like it's a merge of several games in one. Of course it has the whole Left 4 Dead style of campaign; however, ammo is scarce and you have to deal with types of situations. The fact that infection is something that can only be delayed is something I have not seen with many games from this generation of games. I give this game more credit than some of the zombie survival games because. In other zombie games, you only sit in a room crouching over a window facing your gun over the wooden platform to shoot the zombies. It doesn't add to the immersion of 'human ability.' What I am trying to get at, is that it requires more than just your basic game style. It requires you to literally depend on your team and if your team is 'shy' or REALLY! immersed in the game, panic. I've played with groups of people who stayed together, they were having fun and all, but you can tell what was happening. At this point I try to break it and go on an axe-spree to see if anyone is alright. I adore that part of this game. Even the mechanics of it seem a bit polished to me. They give you stuff, but nothing that would let you rush in. Unless it's your first time you think you can, but it really does lead down to strategic ways to get around a map.   The only thing I would consider bad for this game is the few glitches I come across, like grabbing specific ammo for your gun. It won't let you grab it all the time oddly. Also I had several times happen when I got infected by air. I know a zombie did hit me, but he was really out of distance and somehow smacked a kiss to me.   The immerson, the gameplay, the style is why I am rating this as a game to play. The mechanics, the physics, they are good and all, they just need a bit of tweaking. Like I got slingshoted in the air by trying to grab an item that fell into a invisible barrier and took fall damage. Was a great scene, nonetheless, was a glitch/bug.
Zombie purists look no further. If you've got 'L4D' installed, you can uninstall it now and replace it with this.

Unlike the normal zombie games of today's style, No More Room in Hell is a game that gives you a challenge and also fun. Instead of the normal 'you're special' crap that zombie games give you, this game makes yu take a role as a survivor trying to survive and escape the zombie-infested area you are in. And you're not immune, you can become infected, which will kill you, and your re-animated corpse will attept to kill your friends. And unlike today's zombie games, this isn't a world where it seems as if children are non-existant and can't be infected, there are children zombies roaming around, looking for a nice meal, just as the other zombies are.   The game is very realistic, and, as I said earlier, provides a challenge as well as fun. Good luck, you'll need it.

Here is a list of pro's and con's.   PROS:  + The game is free  + You can kill children  + You can play with friends + Zombies ;3 + Not many characters so you don't spend time who you want to be + There's a female character (Although there's only one)  CONS:  - There isn't enough loot around, you can't find any medkits or bandages 90% of the time.  - Guns are bad, they do little damage (Sometimes 3 headshots to kill 1 zombie) and you have to be lucky enough to find bullets (Which you won't)  - Everything you do is very slow, switching weapons, reloading, swinging a melee weapon etc.  - Getting infected is not cool, its annoying and delays the inevitable, pills will only keep you alive for about 7.4 seconds longer.  - If there are multiple people playing, good luck finding a good item.  - Even with 0 ping, melee weapons are very hard to use because you trade hits with zombies most of the time, and you are likely going to get infected.  - You get 'tired' very fast, 3 swings with a sledgehammer and you have to wait 10 hours until you can swing it again.  - The melee weapons are better than guns, but still you will miss most of your swings even at point blank range.  - If you shove a zombie back, they can still attack or grab you immediately after.  - When you get surrounded by a horde of zombies you have to spend a LONG time fighting them off if you cannot run, this becomes tedious and boring.  - The voice acting is not good, the characters sound depressed.  - You movement is restricted, (eg - can't jump on top of cars), it's always at 'ground level' so it becomes frustrating to move around the map.  - You cannot use a flashlight with a 2 handed weapon, this sucks because most of the maps are very dark and all the rifles are 2 handed and the good melee weapons are also 2 handed.  - There's little replay value because of the repetitiveness of the objectives.  - You can't see your own HP, someone has to tell you the color of your name above your head so you can estimate it.  - You can only carry a limited amount of things due to the weight limit.  - You can't carry 2 of the same thing (eg - can't carry 2 medkits or 2 bandages or 2 pills)   Overall this game is great xd

This game is amazing! It's free and if you like hardcore zombie games this is it! If you are a George Romero fan there is plenty of fan service here! Maps from his movies are perfectly recreated! The graphics hold up well considering when this began development, the gameplay is great and the sense of teamwork is unmatched!   The game might seem like a L4D clone but it's not! It's more like a first person Resident Evil Outbreak. You scramble to complete objectives and just one bite has a chance of infecting you, you have the option to tell your friends, keep it to yourself and hope to find pills that hold off infection for a few precious minutes or turn your revolver on yourself and potentially save your allies necks.  People can turn on you over a bottle of pills lol, you never know what's going to happen when ammo and supplies are scarce in a harsh and unforgiving world!   There really isn't anything negative to say about the game, it's free, it's fun and it's a hell of a good time with friends. GET THIS GAME!

No More Room in Hell is a great zombie survival game to play with friends or just with other people online. In my experience NMRiH is a lot of fun if you're a first timer. Once you pass that mark it becomes meh so I highly recommend starting the game with friends who just started the game as well.   Now onto the game itself I had a lot of fun playing it for the first few hours then got some friends to join as well and we had a blast with it! Because we didn't know what to do, really. The combat mechanic is quite simple you can either use your fist, melee weapons such as a fireaxe, and guns to clear any zombies coming at you the choice is yours. You can even choose to avoid the zombie if want!   So far I've read some review that says it's 'impossible' to shove the zombie away once you have come up to them and attack them with some sort of weapon, that is merely false. It's possible just press the shove button right after you attack, quite easy if you ask me.  Like I stated up above the game is fun if your a first-timer and with friends! Once you've get use to it you can easily clear objective maps without killing a zombie by yourself!!!
A great combination of horror and first-person shooter, with the quality to leave any newcomer aghast and asking for more... all of this for not even a penny. Now THAT'S what I call a must-have.

First of all, this is a great game. It does away with the Left 4 Dead (and other similar games) method of 'I'm going to tear through this zombie horde with my guns and run to the exit'. In No More Room in Hell, you will be hard pressed to find two clips for a pistol much less an AK-47 with ~500 rounds (cough L4D cough). This makes the zombie apocalypse seem much more real, and it really reminds me of the TV show “The Walking Dead”. By the same coin, survival time is greatly lengthened with more people playing together, just like it would be in a real life zombie outbreak. If you are having trouble finishing a level, find or make some friends and try to go through the level together.   There is no reason why you shouldn't try this game. It doesn't require Half Life 2, and it runs on the freely available Source SDK Base. If you are tired of playing Left 4 Dead or love “The Walking Dead”, you will probably like this game. At the very least, give it a try.  Verdict: 9.8/10 Because the ammo is unbelievably scarce (you can pick up two boxes of ammo and sometimes get fewer than five bullets) [-0.1] and that you realistically cannot do an objective map by yourself since the zombies respawn [-0.1]. Otherwise, it is a very good game that accurately simulates a zombie apocalypse.

The classic zombie expirience. No futuristic weapons and mutant abominations, just shambling drones against your machete and perhaps a few bullets. I don't know why there aren't more games like this, it's almost perfect.   -slow and unwieldly zombies that become deadly in numbers and in close quarters, a single mistake could end your perfect round  -dark and dreary maps with a terrifying ambiant soundtrack, but even without the atmosphere, the maps are very well designed and provide a diverse expirience  -low key horror that just sort of gets to you after a while, very anxious feeling to the gameplay  -satisfying weapons that reward patience and swiftness  A few nitpicks: glitchy animations, weapon switching is a bit weird looking sometimes and zombies can take 2 shoves because of hitbox glitching. Mostly fine though.

It's a good game. It has its flaws, but overall it's with worth playing.  First of all it's a survival game, so you're underequipped most of the time.  It's focused on atmosphere and the experience of being challenged more than it is about action itself. If you're looking for action you're better off with L4D2. This is much more than just an action game. Single zombies are usually fairly easy to handle (if you have a melee weapon or a gun). Large groups can be challenging, especially because you run out of ammo and stamina quickly.  One silly thing is that in scenario modes there are spawn points for zombies (often in rooms with no windows and one entrance), so at times you will find yourself attacked from behind by a randomly spawned zombie just after you had cleared a certain area or part of a building. This can seriously ruin the mood.  Sometimes the game is kind of cryptic, and requires you to use very specific items for certain tasks, while at other times virtually any item will do (a good example is having to use a chainsaw to cut through planks in the attic, while being able to pry them off in almost all other areas in game).  Online multiplayer is what ruins the game (at least for me it does). While single-player and LAN games are indeed fun and entertaining, playing with random people might ruin the game for you. You will come across people making fart sounds on voice channel and killing you for ammo and resources. The devs give you no tools to deal with that other than leaving the game and joining another one with hopes of a better outcome.

Let's nutshell this:  Pros: -Incredibly survival based. You don't know how many bullets until you check your gun, for example. Your only indication of health is your vision. -Realistic feeling of infection. Eyes will strain up. Your survivor will start to panic. All the way until he/she suddenly zombifies and goes after your friends. -Good use of putting up barricades. Barricade animation could use some work, but is overall better than most other games. -Unique reloading animations depending on gun used and how many bullets are left. -Major focus on headshots. Torso shots are just not worth it. -Incredibly challenging overall. -Lovely soundtrack. Takes me back to NIN's Ghosts album. -Amazing with friends. -It's free. I'm not sure if HL2 is required, so consider downloading and starting it first to see if HL2 is required. If HL2 is required, then go buy HL2 as well. There's really no reason for anyone to not have that game anyway.  Cons: -The L4D community is here. That means everyone joins a team-based game and does nothing but kill teammates, troll around, or lone wolf everything. -Ammo is unrealistic. One example would be a house that has a sniper rifle sitting next to a big box that looks like the casing for said rifle. Guess how many bullets it has, despite looking like it's against a stash? Two. Yes. Just two. -Mechanics are archaic. Weapon hits don't look as if they connect, as range of the swing and the actual range are incredibly different. This is also the case with zombie grabs. -Similar to other horror survival games that aren't finished. Falling so much as a foot could probably kill you. -Interface, servers, and pretty much everything in the game uses the same engine as Half-life 2, since it is technically a mod. That means that there is a huge lack in ease of use, and the overall gamepad use has a lot of work ahead of itself. This also means that even the 'dedicated' servers are really just user servers. And yes. There isn't very much network optimization in this, causing terrible results with lag. In a zombie game, that is bad news. -Graphics feel very unoptimized for this type of game. What would net you 80fps in Half-Life 2 will probably net you 40fps here. This really shouldn't be the case, as the graphics are just about the same, if not worse than Half-Life 2. -I'm just going to list 'L4D Community' here again, because literally everyone in the game has no clue what they're doing and will refuse to be useful. -Ammo weighs way more than it should, which is bad considering that there is no help to indicate what ammo goes with what gun. I'm not kidding. Picking up three boxes of shells will literally take up 1/4 of your overall inventory. -While I'm at it, let me emphasize that ammo is VERY PICKY in this game. Good luck finding the right gun for the right ammo most of the time. Keep a sledgehammer with you at all times.  So there you have it. Think 'Dead Island meets Left 4 Dead....with an engine that might as well be from the late 90s.' ...but when you create a game hell-bent on survival, or else death, and yet you have an entire community that is acting on just the opposite... This is just not a game worth playing with strangers, and (thanks to the impressive 8 player max) that's most likely what you'll be paired up with through most of the game.

This game is basically a Left for Dead with up to 8 player parties. Start off in a safe room, grab some gear, head out to find the objective, finish the objective, rinse and repeat a couple times, until you can get extracted.   The game is kind of glitchy but hey, it free to play.  Many servers are on the classic setting which basically means that once you die, you're dead until the end. That's my one main beef with the game. It's a game, people want to play, they don't want wait forever to see if the team wipes or finishes it. They need to make that a hardcore setting, for those that wish to challenge themselves. Because you will die at least once or twice in a session.   The good thing is that there are some casual servers which allow you to respawn after a timer.  The guns and ammo are pretty thin on vanilla servers. if that's not your thing, there are many 'Choose your gear' servers as well. When you spawn, you choose some gear and get back to playing.  (TL;DR) At the end of the day, I think this is worth the DL because it's free. It gave me a few hours of enjoyment and I'll probably come back and play again some time.

Ingredients  Serves: 12  250g self-raising flour 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon 400g caster sugar 350ml vegetable oil 4 eggs 350g grated carrots 120g chopped walnuts Cream cheese icing 225g cream cheese 110g margarine, softened 450g icing sugar 120g chopped walnuts 1 teaspoon vanilla extract  Method Prep:30min › Cook:30min › Ready in:1hr  Preheat the oven to 180 C / Gas 4. Grease two 23cm round cake tins. In a medium bowl, stir together the flour, cinnamon and sugar. Add the oil and eggs, mix until blended, then stir in the carrots and nuts. Divide the cake mixture evenly between the two prepared tins. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven. A skewer inserted into the cake should come out clean. Cool cakes on wire racks before removing from tins. To make the icing: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and cream cheese, add the sugar and cream well. Stir in the nuts and vanilla. Use to fill and ice the cooled cake layers. Tips You can easily halve the amount of sugar to 200g for a less sweet cake.   please end me m9

A bland mix of Left for Dead and Call of Duty: Zombies with several gaping flaws in its game design. While I will admit that the infection mechanic is certainly realistic, it is the furthest thing from fun that I can imagine since it is essentially a timer ticking away until your death, and it can be shortened even more by stating your infection to your teammates, who will all gladly shoot you in the head. And yes, while there is a wide variety of weapons, you'll be lucky to find at least one that isn't already taken by players more experienced than you who have memorized the map. It also doesn't help that most of the available melee weapons in the game do as much damage to the innumerable horde of zombies as a marshmallow attached to a wet Q-tip. I understand that a lot of work was put into this game, but with punishing difficulty, near-useless weapons, overused mechanics, and an absolutely brutal community, I just can't recommend it to anyone but masochists.

Good concept on paper, unrefined execution. Clunky, stiff controls (and not because of a sense of 'realism', as though you had some real weight and a rhythm to your walking or running pace. Feels strangely dated and unpolished, despite being two years old. If it's realistic to not have a tooltip for the ammo type that you're pointing at, well... in the real world, you could pick up and READ THE BOX in front of your face, rather than at arm's length. You would also have an idea of how much spare ammo you were carrying; hiding the UI until you hold a button doesn't make the game more 'realistic', it's a contrived way of limiting your available information. Could have been implemented another way; you could have to look down at your cargo pants and see how many boxes you have stuffed into your pockets, or visually inspect your revolver or clip to count ammo left. Anyway, I think I would have found this fun if I played it 7 or 8 years ago, but it's hard to hold this up against more modern, standalone titles with more sophistication, or the many other games jumping all over the zombie survival bandwagon.

Very slow and choppy/buggy gameplay. The animations for attacking are very poor, and the game looks like it is run straight out of the CS:S engine. C'mon now...Where's the kick ♥♥♥ graphics, details, animations, and intensity? Every other zombie's face is the SAME as the last. It's a cute Left for Dead knockoff pretty much, except this is mostly scavenging for ammo, and hitting zombies with melee weapons, and completing tedious and boring objectives. It's pretty much a chore to play. There's not really a storyline either. It's just complete all the objectives, and get extracted. There's not much of a sandbox aspect. If you're looking for that, go play Day Z Standalone. Is this seriously the main release?     TL;DR Cool concept, poorly executed.

I just tried to play this game for about an hour, alone, so I could learn how to play. What I learned is that you can't play alone because you will die. What I learned is that the controls are more sluggish than Jabba the Hutt. What I learned is that even if you charge up a melee attack and swing the attack, if a zombie attacks you the zombie always hits and you always miss, and then you're stuck in a dance of missing attacks until you die.   If I click my mouse to attack, I should attack. I shouldn't stand there like a mouth-breathing idiot for three seconds, then wind up, and then attack five seconds later. This 'combat' (anal ♥♥♥♥) is slower than the knife in the first Resident Evil game and half as effective.   I realize it's supposed to be a 'realistic' survival horror kind of game and not a Left for Dead kind of game, but dumbing down the controls and making the players attack slower than the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zombies they're fighting is just ridiculous. Couple it with one magazine of ammo and extremely poor hitbox detection and you have yourself shooting zombies in the head two to three times before the server 'sees' it and kills the zombie, that is, if they aren't already on top of you in a ground-n-pound. Plus, when wielding a melee weapon the right mouse button doesn't seem to do anything, and you have to hunt down the default 'V' key to shove zombies away when they get too close.   Whoever designed these controls needs to be fed to a pack of rabid zombies. I don't know where you get off naming this game 'No More Room in Hell' because I'll tell you: Hell is not full. Hell is being stuck playing this awful game.   Why even have weapons? Why not just make left mouse turn your character around, pull down his pants, and bend over?
There has to be room in hell, because I believe that God will send these game developers straight to it.

This is a slow, terrible and cumbersome first person shooter mod for Half Life 2 that feels like a hardcore version of Left 4 Dead. Your multiplayer co-op party needs to carry out objectives in maps and mostly just stay alive. Its pretty easy to stay alive and not die, but its difficult to do anything else. First of all, the game is pretty slow. I mean the animations of your character are slow. When you switch to a flash light, it is always off to start with, then you need to turn it on.... WITH BOTH HANDS! Watch as your character slowly turns on a flashlight with his left hand while holding it with his right. Then there's the inventory system that has a good use of space management. The catch is that you really can't hold all that much. Your ammo takes up space, which is logical, its just I can't imagine when it comes down to carrying a sledge hammer, flashlight and a rifle that you can't carry all three at once.  You walk pretty slow (there is a sprint button), which is okay, but you swing pretty slow and the zombies shuffle their way toward you. Oh and when you get bitten, its like a poison that will slowly drain your health until you're dead. Once you're dead, your character becomes a zombie while you spectate as a ghost. Reloading takes quite a while, but maybe other video games have spoiled me into reloading fast when the reality is that it takes a while.  Carrying things is a chore, don't drop a key next to a door, because you'll never be able to pinpoint the key on the ground from the door. Maps have invisible walls preventing exploration, even when it looks like there is exploration.  Another downside is, this isn't really a campaign, its just more of a series of multi player co-op maps. Left 4 Dead is just better. There's a reason why this took 2 years to make it to Steam. Its just a cumbersome game and maybe that adds to the survival horror aspect, but eh its not for me. This isn't an action game, its a slow beast walking toward you when you can't reload your rifle fast enough.

Even if you can't afford Left 4 Dead, I still wouldn't recommend this game. Obviously, this mod tried to be a cooperative zombie FPS that would require teamwork and be difficult, but I beg to differ. The entire difficulty of the game is trying to figure out what's going on, because the game offers no feedback whatsoever. The zombies never flinch and don't bleed, and not even the guns you carry have any kind of effects that indicate you're shooting, which is why you can never know if you hit a zombie or not. And it would have been nice if there were any animations in the game that didn't last 2 or 3 frames. By the way, there's no reloading. Shoot with your useless pistol a few times, and you'll be stuck with your even less helpful baseball bat, which apparently has a range of 1 pixel.

First: you WILL download this. Second:You WILL pick your character. Third:you WILL pick a server/make one/play by yourself. Fourth:You WILL pick thine weapons. Fith.....You WILL die.....and then you will die again...and again, yet you WILL not get ♥♥♥♥♥♥, you WILL not quit playing....you WILL just play more....alot more.  Ok i cant exagerate that enough, this is a top notch zombie game if i may say so, you may be like 'But omg dayz, omg what about other fps zgames like Dead Island and Left 4 Dead?' yea...those are FUN...this is harder than your daddy when he wakes up in the morning. when you join a server, you may be waiting for the default weapon, the control layout tutorial, the stretched out hand waiting to hold yours as you trot through this game....all i can say 'HAHAHAAHAHAHAHAHAHA! THATS FOOKING HILARIOUS!', but no seriously this game will mentally 'Kick' you in the face as hard as it can, as many times as it can. so before you can play this game you need to learn how to respect a game like this, this is no infinite ammo, one bash with a axe and zombies dead BS no its more like the one slap at YOU and YOUR DEAD. you may be waiting for the hallway with 1-3 zombies so you can get used to the walker, the runner, the kiddies (YES THEY HAVE KIDS, THEY RUN LIKE HELL AND ARE SHORT AND HARD TO HIT! P.S LITTLE GIRL AND BLACK BOY....YOU WERE WARNED!) but this does not happen AT ALL its more like, lets shove 10-20 at you at once, lets make you defend a door your trying to go out of, lets make them think if they team up in the gun shop with all the ammo they just got, they can clear the city...yea, not gonna work, they respawn, and you run out of ammo period.   So when and if you do complete a mission, your about out of breath and on the verge of having a stroke, you may be thinking 'Pfft this guys lying, he doesent no ♥♥♥♥'....trust me, read the other reviews THIS IS A VERY DIFFICULT GAME!   but to sum it up, best free fps zombie game on the planet, low graphics meaning you can play it on a low grad lap top, lots of tools to figure out if they will actually kill what you intend to use them on, and loads of fun, i give this a gazzilion out of 10 because it is a game that gets to the point of, your here, your dead, get use to it =).....

It's an overall great game that gives you a really exciting experience full of action, strategy and the sweet feel of self acomplishment when finally reach the end of a map. The problem is that most of the time you will be in a server full of histeric pre adolescent trying to troll you as hard as they can.  Positive:  +Real free to play game. This is the real ♥♥♥♥♥ not like other freemium scams that sells you the best stuff.  +Realistic gameplay. It's almost as real as source can be. It's good because there is already a bunch of zombie games that fills you with bullets and weapons (L4D1&2) so NMRIH adds something new to the gaming universe. Yes, the learning curve IS a cliff but won't be like that in a real world? I mean if a zombie apocalypse takes place most of us won't be able to survive comfortably until we learn by force a lot of things. This is somewhat like that: taking all the juice require reading some tutorials avaible online or by experience.  +Extended gameplay. There are a lot's of maps/opportunities, and two gameplays. There are also third party maps that add even more posibilities.  +Active development. Developers are adding things constantly. For example in August they added a new weapon, three characters and four maps. There is a release at 3/4 months so it gives you an excuse to come back time to time.  Negative:  -50% of the players are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who doesn't even try it. The best way of playing this is being aware of all the posibilites out there, picking just what you need and doing things not just for you alone but for everyone (like carrying ammo or weapons to a safe place). But most of the time you will see people picking up everything just because they don't know how this works. They will get killed fast and they will eat you as a zombie.  -20% of the players are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who will troll you. There are some that doesn't care but also there are others who care enough to make everybody elses life more ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Both groups are a pain in the ♥♥♥. So be prepare of trolls blocking hallways, stealing weapons and ammo they don't need or won't use. Don't waste your time going to a TK server. You will get killed by a 15 years old boy who will laugh at you like if they were 8 years old.  -You need at least 5 non-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s players more to have real fun here. And sometimes you only need one good troll to screw it all. So the posibilities of a good game are really small.  Conclusion:  Give this a try. It's free. Luckily enough it will give you one of the most satifsactory experiences avaible nowadays. You can also create your own server which will give you the posibility of get rid of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. (up to 8 players so you don't need a supercomputer neither a corporative internet connection).  Score:  Game: 9/10  Community: 4/10  Gameplay: 5/10 (it can be 10/10 if you get into a nice server).

'Redaker Zones' Orange 84. World War Z book reference and a really clever idea for a Zombie game.  This game is much more about survival than horror and if you want a good shoot em up with powerful weapons and lots of ammo...this isn't it. You need to scrimp and save your rounds, work with your team mates instead of hording for yourself and get really handy with a melee weapon. This game is clearly made by fans of Romero zombie movies and Max Brooks' books and as such the learning curve will be very steep if you are used to a more forgiving zombie game like L4D. Take some time to read the manual because the game does not offer any tutorial or hand holding...you are full throttle the first time you log in.

I don't know why everyone is giving this game such good reviews! I thought this game would be extremley fun, but when comes down to it, I was really disappointed. Clipping issues, animation bugs, AI tracking goes wonky, and the hit boxing goes to ♥♥♥♥. I got this game awhile ago when was still in early development. I was thinking they'll probably just fix it because it's still in development, but I was wrong. I uninstalled and reinstalled on one computer. Still was terrible. Your character plays like a 50-year-old habitual smoker who hasn't gone outside in months. Wheezing after running for a few steps, this worthless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shows up in a Half-Life 1 mod, as an unending, slow horde of genuinely brain-dead yet somehow lethal zombies gradually lurch towards him as he struggles and fails to fend them off alongside up to seven other hopelessly crippled nursing home patients.  It's not fun. It's not even remotely like fun. Fun is not even what the designers were going for, but the kind of survivalism they were going for gets drowned in a lot of 'Why the hell can't I put this key in my pocket?!' shenanigans and just plain bad design.  As a free game it's not worth the price.

We've all wanted that zombie game. That 'one'. you know what i'm talking about. the one in which the zombies actually shuffle at you because you're gun went off by accident. That one that lets you take the decisions into your own hands, like letting an infected friend live because they gave you the last of the ammo later. then waking away alone because everyone was killed. The guilt. The fear. The excitement of watching a long lived character put a gun in his or her mouth because they know they won't survive seeing another zombie child eating an ally, because they were too scared to blow its brains out.   The wait is over. This game has it all. realism, challenge, and even buttons for suicide, pulling out the magazine to check how many bullets you have left, and even one for shoving those little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s away from you.   But in honesty, what really sold it for me, was the fact that every bite could be your last chance. I play with my sister a lot. we're really into the genre, me especially, and we needed something new since standalones glitches and disappointments. Soon we'll be trying out with the 8 players, but so far wwe're following the advice, and sticking to friends. as an example of the amazing experiences we have had so far.   Chinatown. The streets above us no longer bustle with the busy footsteps of strangers, but with the familiarity of the dead. The End has come. Yet we have just begun. We'd scouted the streets many times before, and had even killed a few of them, with our short notice combination of weapons, ranging from old rusty pipes, to huge Rebars. I could tell you about the many times we'd attempted to reach the gun shop from the subway, but the tries were a many. it was the final time, however, that I have told on many occasions.   Me and my sister had held off enough of the horde to fuel the generator of the door to finally get it open. We'd already raided the gun shop, but with such a little amount of ammo, it was still unclear whether we'd make it. I reached for the door switch, and praised the heavens. the door opened, and we were free. I was the first to duck under it as it rose, my sister the second, just barely making it through. What we didn't expect, that there was another horde waiting on the other side. because of our experience in the risky task, we had to make the decision to run through them. unfortunatley, I'd learned to travle light with small arms, whilst my sister had an experience in rifles. I'd seen the difficulty in loading them, when she covered me in the shop whislt I scrounged and searched for the ammo type for my favourite gun, the .22 pistol. She had favoured the SKS, but was betrayed when her ammo count became nil. whilst she moved backwards deeper into the sanctuary of shelves and bodies, she neglected to watch her back. I had managed to load in time, i aimed the pistol over the shelves that divided us, firing a pellet into the rotting corpse's head.   This moment of heroism was briefly lived. As we avoided the hoard in the second part of the street, we'd spotted an alley. I kept running through and pushed as many as i could, but neglected to note how the dead do not stop their stalkerish ways. I made it through the alley to find a Beretta pistol and more ammo, along with a crowbar. I splattered a zombies head as it closed in on me, but was too late to make it back to save my sister from the horde. As I ran back to save her, she was bitten. A bite means infection, but we would have still find a way to sustain it, until at least we were rescued. But this dream was shattered as i saw her still be surrounded by the rest of them. I quickly had to attend to the danger that i was still presented with, splitting three more heads with the gun. The time was enough for my sister to rise again. I turned back in time, just to shoot my second to last bullet into her head. maybe as a sign of thanks for the times she had led me, or as a way of avoiding the regret of not running in to save her. Not that any of it mattered anyway, as the last bullet was spent on myself.   besides, we could always do it again.
