I recommend this game to zombie game fans, but, for others, I am skeptical that you will be among those to like this game.  I love this game, I really do, but, after taking a long break from it, I discovered why it got a little stale over prolonged periods of play. Like the Doom franchise, you have to get from Point A to Point B, but with objectives to do so in between to get there. That being said, the majority of the time, it's fun to panic with a team through zombie infested streets and tunnels. But, it gets old really fast over time as your progress through the same order of business over and over again.  Not only does this get boring after this, but, the team play does not work with the gameplay if the team does not play like a team. It pains me to say it, but, some players can kill the experience and really mess things up for the others enjoying the game. It doesn't work all the time and, unfortunately, games like these could become rather stale without friends who know what they're actually doing during a mission.  Also, what catches my eye is the lack of effort in terms of trying to push the genre further, regardless of if they actually wanted to or not. Gunplay, when ammo is available, is sort of satisfying, only when gunning down a horde of zombies with an M-16 is actually possible. Melee combat gets bloody, which is AWESOME, but suffers from very stressful moments where influence by your teammates can affect a good melee between you and a handful of zombies begging to be whacked. You get tired way too easily, which kills immersion when in fact in some situations you can do more than what you might expect of a regular average joe in a similar situation. The game loses immersion this way and really makes players a lot more vulnerable than planned in terms of gameplay mechanics.  Also what is puzzling is also the lack of diverse missions with very different objectives. For example, almost every single Point A to Point B map, there is always one objective that pertains unlocking various amounts of doors. I expected something more than that from a game that is a lot more immersive than Left-4-Dead. Other objectives require retrieving items and fuel, grabbing keys, clearing exits, etc. It gets repetitive a lot and I find myself turned off by the repetitve nature of its escape game mode. But, there is a Survival game mode and that even gets stressful. What the creators didn't account for was the lack of proper teamplay that a small number of the player base display. I found myself always getting the scraps of supplies after many of my teammates bum rushed me and left me alone to fend for myself while everyone partied with shotgun shells, assault rifle rounds, and knives. I know, I should've left first, but, the moment that you hear that a supply drop arrives, you may not even get something worth the horrible trek from where you were, which could be on the OTHER SIDE OF THE MAP, or even just right next to the adjacent room where the drop arrives.  Also, in this lack of effort argument is the lack of characters to choose. I have many female friends who have been turned off by this section only because of this, which, seems small, but, it isn't. I know they work so hard on this game, but the character selection in this game is severly limited. It ruins the immersion in the game, since it prevents players from completely immersing themselves in the universe of NMRiH. Immersion was the goal here and character customization sort of dropped its points.   This game is fun when it can be. It can be intense, it can be scary and it sure can be addictive, but, when the other players allow it to or when the flawed game mechanics, repetitive play, sort-of drowned out immersion, or the lack of unique modes of play begin to show itself. I love this game, I really do, but, this game's flaws, mechanics, and lack of complete immersion take so many points from it where I can only recommend it to hardcore zombie gamers, zombie fans, or horror FPS fans. Sorry NMRiH, I have to say that I was disappointed, but, at least entertained.  64/100

This is by far the most realistic and challenging zombie survival game I have played.   It isn't your typical 'You're immune to the virus and you need to travel to saftey while shooting all of the zombies' game. This game is realistic, making you have to be resourceful, smart, and cunning.   The most realistic parts?  The lack of readily available weapons and ammo adds a great challenge to the game. You will find that you start with a decent supply of ammo, but you soon will use it all on zombies, making ammo harder and harder to find. And that's just if you can find the right weapon for it.  You are also subceptible to infection, so if you are bitten, you need to quickly find the counter-virus.   Would I reccomend this game? Yes.

No More Room in Hell is a hardcore version of L4D2 without the special infected. Game is created on a modified version of HL2 engine. It's a pretty good game if you want to lay back and shoot some zombies.  Pros -Realistic gunplay -Makes you nervous or uncomfortable thanks to the dreadful music and tone -Makes you desperate to find medkits or bandages, or even pills to keep you alive and not infected -Zombies are DEADLY, one bit and you're gone, unless you find pills which are rare. -Ever wanted to be freaked out by little kid zombies? or even running zombies? This is the game -Dev is active  Cons -No story whatsoever, it only shows a fraction of a story by the loading menu cutscenes -Textures are a bit....strange. The cars appear to be made by hand, either to avoid copyright bs or again, crafted by hand. -No FOV changing, 60 fov at all times.  8/10 could be better.

This game is the most interesting Zombie game that I have ever played.  It show how we can survive in zombie apocalypse, It is not alike to Day-Z or Infestation. This game is about Co-op, helping each other, not to kill each other.  Limited ammo, variety of maps, lots of objective and guns, Hand-to-Bite Combat, custom server modification (Like unlimited ammo or unlimited supplies), it's the best.  The other thing is when our friend got infected, it made us hesitated. It will let us choose two ways, first shoot him in the face, second is give them pills. 10/10 shot them in their face. [ME TOO.]  The last one is game system. It look real the most in any zombie games. We can choose the characters and their sound, it made our characters not all same like infestation. In-game system has made out really cool. We don't always need to choose melee weapons to fight hand-to-hand fight with them, cause some guns have 'Bayonet' to fight with or we just press 'V' to push them back and shoot them in the face.   Pros 1. Free 2. Limited ammo 3. Customized server 4. Lots of objective 5. Weapons 6. Realistic motion (Characters & Zombies) 7. Real-life apocalypse  8. Lots of characters and sounds 9. Great BGM and sound effect 10. Fantastic game system  11. Lots of maps 12. Weapons-Ammo checking (It doesn't show us while we are shooting.) 13. Lots of gamemodes 14. Enable cheats {some servers} (press Y and type !guns)  Cons 1. Server sometimes it doesn't keep in history. 2. Tired so damm fast!!!!  100/10 of players who started to play first time would continue playing forever.

This is a   really   well made game and it shows on a lot of things.  The guns? Satisfying to use.  Melee weapons? Balanced and takes a while to learn how to use every one of them properly. (No one ever said that using sledgehammers and kitchen knives against hordes of zombies was easy)  The maps? Realistic looking and every time you restart in an escape map, you have a different route to take.  The zombies? Logical and there's always hordes of them giving very little time to catch your breath. (And stamina if you spent all of it trying to get a few zombies out of the way)   Shame i can't say the same about the general playerbase. Always wasting their ammo, getting themselves killed, killing zombies that are not even in the way (You're not even supposed to kill all of them unless it's a survival map. BTW, anyone willing to try doing a pacifist run on every single escape map? Would watch your run if you recorded it.), not sharing ammo if they have extra ammo they don't have a gun for, never helping teammates if they are nearly dead etc.  And of course, infinite ammo servers.   But giving something a bad rating just because of a crappy community is something only an idiot would do. *Cough cough* Garry's mod *cough*   Heavily recommended.   8/10

This is one of the better free games on Steam. The gameplay is hard to get used to, but after a few matches you definitely start getting the hang of things. This does not play anything like Left 4 Dead. Gameplay is not as fast paced, but definitely just as intense. One scratch or bite from a zombie has a chance of infecting you and guns and ammunition are scarce.  Probably the closest thing to a hardcore zombie experience out there. The lobby system is a bit cluttered and messy, but hopefully with further updates they'll fix all the glitches and continue improving the experience. It is a Half-Life 2 mod, after all, but I think it's safe to say that they successfully seperated their mod from its source and created their own unique game.  It's free, so it's definitely at least worth a shot.

In my opinion, I think No More Room in Hell is the best zombie survival game i ever played. Unlike other zombie games were you probably start off with a large gun and start shooting zombies with a ton of ammo, in this game ammo is limited so you'll often use melee weapons, which is actully a real case scenario if there is a zombie apocolypse in real life. This is also the only zombie game where I have seen that when you get bit you actully become infected and over time no matter what your health is you will die and turn into a zombie. The only thing I disliked about the game is that if you have enough experience in the game and join a team of new players, it ruins the fun since they are new with the game and dont know how to play or what the objective is which just leaves you by yourself with no back up. You know a noob when you see a noob in the game, to any of the people who are reading this and have played the game for quite some time, you probably seen what noobs do in the following, 1. They take all the ammo for themselves 2.When caught by a zombie they attack rather than shove 3. They dont defend the zones in survival mode. I always encounter this numerous times while playing the game. However I always like it when there are international people on the server and chat in their laungage by the chat box or mic, to me it's always fun to hear it and see it despite not knowing what they're saying. This game features only one thing: Realistic zombie apocolyptic experience. I highly highly recommend this to anyone who wants the real deal of a zombie survival game. Being a fan of hard games I was excited to see there's a F2P game that focuses on cautiousness rather than a quick triggerfinger. On top of that there aren't any ingame cash transactions so there's no 'pay 2 win' either. It seems that the developers keep in touch with the community, which is always nice. According to the shop site there are still lots of content to be added in the future.  The game's graphics aren't the best but being an ascended mod running on the Source engine I guess that's not too big a deal. It also has little to no impact on the gameplay and atmosphere.  The sounds on the other hand are quite nice. You get your typical shooter acustics- footsteps, gun sounds, melee smacks, zombie groans, but the soundtrack is where the game's audio really shines. There are lots of different pieces (in style of soundtracks like The Walking Dead's and State of Decay's) that play according to the current situation in the game.   The game's atmosphere is awesome. In contrast to L4D's cannon fodder zombies, the undead in NMRIH are a true menace. Even a single zed can take down an uncautious player in a few hits and bites. This level of difficulty manages to deliver a constant feeling of threat, something I missed in (the flawed but great) State of Decay, to name a current example (especially thanks to the OP cars in that game). From frantically running around, dodging zombies left and right while trying to fulfill the map's final task, to carefully sneaking around in a mansion or theater, covering each other while scrounging for ammo or medicine- the game manages to present an  atmosphere that's worthy of being called 'survival horror' (something that's become rare in today's horror games).  NMRIH tries to abstain from using a HUD. There's no health and stamina meter, so the player has to keep an eye on the character's heartbeat, breathing and vision. The amounts of ammo in your gun are only shown when the player takes the time to actually check the magazine. This might seem a bit overwhelming or confusing at first but it surely adds to the atmosphere. Something that took a bit of getting used to is the handling of the melee weapons. In my first few matches I found myself constantly missing the zeds right in front of me, leaving my char open to be grappled and overwhelmed. There's no real sense of 'depth', if you will, to the melee attacks, which means that the player has to learn about the actual ranges of his weapons. A few hours later I can say that I know my favourite weapons and I know how to use them (without the game actually becoming too easy), although there are some other weapons I don't like to choose because they just suck in my opinion- but that's not an issue of the game itself.  All in all I just can say: Grab a friend, download this gem, go out there and survive! Seriously, even if you find yourself not liking this game, at least give it a chance. It'll cost you nothing but a bit of time. Having a friend to play with and to actually communicate with while playing helps a lot (as always)- because someone you can depend on is always nice to have in case the world ends ;)

This is one of those interesting games that you know you want to play. Though this game has several flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience with it. Beginning with the cons: - Manually searching for a server can be a pain - Joining can often lead to waiting until the next round (takes a long time) - Server issues (though its often the people's fault not this game) - Hit detection with melee weapons seem a bit off  Now with the pros (and there's plenty): + Getting infected, this is actually pretty awesome and new to this type of genre of games (surprisingly) + Graphics are pretty good for a half-life 2 mod + Child zombies (finally someone with guts) + Realistic survival (not much ammo, so a lot of scavenging) + ONLY ONE LIFE, this looks like it should be in cons but quite the contrary considering that if a player ends up dying, they'll have to wait until the next round so make that one life count  That's pretty much the basic things. There's more packed into the game itself. One last thing to say is, unfortunately this is one of those games where you have to download and play it yourself. While this 'review' highlights the good and the bad, the game is a bit lacking. I recommend this, yes but is it worth playing over and over until your eyes melt and you have carpel tunnel....well play it and see if its your cup of tea.

I will say that No More Room In Hell is a fun game. It presents a pretty realistic layout of what would actually happen in an apocalypse and presents the need to work as a team. There are a variety of weapons and the graphics are ok. The only problem is that like any zombie game (obviously), it tends to get repetitive and maps, while they can change routes you take, becomes repetitive as well. Luckily, this is a modding community so many maps are available to download and most (and I say most) maps present new objective/survival based maps. The jist of it is this, if you like zombie games get it. If not, don't. Everyone knows about the infamy of constant zombie games released so if you don't like zombie games and think they are going to get boring than don't get this game. Also it's a free game so you can always download this game and try it out, and if you hate it, than give it a bad review or complain to yourself that it sucks.

This game used to be a mod for Half-Life 2. Can you beleive that! I played this mod for the first time and fell in love with it! If you want a realistic, zombie co-op mod, {Ahem!} ...Game, this is the one for you! If you like Left-4-Dead, but wish it was aLOT more realistic, here you go! The only thing that Left-4-Dead has in common with NMRiN is that co-op is key. Singleplayer is not recommended, {which is bad if you have no friends.} and once you get bitten twice (within a short period of time,) its game over eventually. The best thing about this Mod, {A-Ahem!!} GAME is that its free. You now, that word that you bearly ever see on the price tag of a game. Sure the game has flaws, but what game doesn't! It WAS good too. In 2011 in Moddb while it was still a mod it made first place for multiplayer. Now you may ask which is better between Left-4-Dead and NMRiH, well, I like more of a realistic touch, so, I beleive that NMRiH is better. I highly recommend this Mo- {A-A-Ahem!!!} Game to a lot of people.

For a Half-Life 2 mod, this game is stunningly good. The animations and the improved lighting effects are the most prominent changes visible in the game; another thing noted was the atmosphere the game sets - the scarce ammunition, the post-apocalyptic setting and the difficulty of the game made this one to remember. A final thing that I found surprisingly executed was the story, even though it has been used by many games before; but what makes this game different is that they stayed true to that feeling of 'being a survivor'.  One of the things I will criticise the game upon is its friendly-fire mechanic. This can be easily abused (from personal experience) and makes the game frustrating if you're playing on a server with random people.  Apart from that, this is a really well-developed game that I can find a lot of enjoyment from when I play with friends. +1

At first the controls are a bit clunky, and the zombies seem a bit unfairly powerful. But as I learned more about the game I realized how fun it is. This is a very addicting game, especially in objective mode. Here are my tips: bind a key to 'unload weapon' so you can take ammo from similar weapons you find. 2 normal strikes from a lead pipe kill any zombie. You can also use a flashlight with any one handed weapon system. Stay away from lower caliber guns like 9mm and 22lr; they take 2 headshots to kill. Also dont waste ammo on lone zombies, melee them with a decent reach weapon.

Absolutely brilliant mod with excellent gameplay design. Doesn't treat the Zombie survival genre with the 'usual gotta kill them all' cliche but more of a feeling of a pure struggle for survival. Encourages teamwork and strategic planning and maintains a sense of realism from features from manually counting ammo and a minimal HUD (heads up display) which makes you rely on guessing your bullet trajectory. Features a great selection of weapons and constant additions to the current arsenal from the Dev's. Also features visceral melee combat that with the right timing can have a big impact against your enemies.  A negative point (if you find this point to be a negative) about this mod is that if your looking for a game with action set pieces and Call of Duty-esque action your looking in the wrong place as this mod aims for a realism aesthetic .Generally great rounded zombie wave survival.

This is a really good game for something Steam would make Free To Play. I enjoy how it's set up, just raw hardcore survival. I say hardcore literally. This game throws lines and lines of 'Zeeks' at your weakly fortified hideout. You and any other survivors you may be with have to constantly watch your backs, keep a gun - and crowbar - handy at all times, and be ready to switch from flashlight to rifle in a split second. However on the downside, the game could use some improvments. I never liked how Left 4 Dead looked, it was too 'common'. This game looks a lot like it and if not that - exactly like it. Another matter is the ammo deal. I can't tell what ammo goes with what gun, and that's a problem when you're running, gunning and scavenging. My final concern is that this game could be better with less 'pick a person and get thrown into the fray' gameplay and more immersive gameplay. It needs a character creation, the ability to name your character and some sort of level format.   Aside from the entire game, this would make an absolutley awesome free-roam apocalypse game.

I HIGHLY recommend this game -- even if you're not into FPS, zombies, shooting, gore, or cooperation. Why? Because it's FREE. There is no payment model in this stand-alone Half-Life 2 mod even though after playing for dozens of hours, I think it deserves some monetary compensation. So what is the game about and why do I recommend it?  Well for starters the atmosphere is both gripping and exciting - trying to navigate your away through dark city streets dimly lit by burning car wrecks and the countless hordes of the undead forces the players on their heels. The game's varied soundscape, which includes such noises as the skull-splitting crack of a zombie's head from a powerful swing by fire axe, to the grumble and gurgles of nearby zombies that have yet to detect you... and from the frightened voices of teammates heard through fully-integrated in-game voice chat, to their cries for you to help them as they are mercilessly being eaten alive. The range of emotions and claustrophobia tense the player, eliciting such panic and fight-or-flight response that it may put you in danger, and cost both you and potentially others their lives.   This isn't just a concern of running and gunning - which it sometimes can be - if you have enough ammunition and want to move at a faster pace, or are at risk of being completely surrounded and devoured by the shambling masses of rotting flesh... But above all the shooting and gore, this game's also about methodical teamwork and calculated risks that serve to not frustratingly overwhelm the player, but to deepen their immersion and enrich the scope of the game into a wider breadth of enjoyment and quick-thinking.  Each element working in tandem with the next - brings both the individual player, and team together as a cohesive whole into confrontation with a vast array of challenges and threats to overcome. There's so much fun and excitement to experience in this - let me emphasize one more time - FREE GAME, that it takes a few deep breaths at the end of a successful (or perhaps unsuccessful) mission to collect one's thoughts and comprehend what in the hell just happened!   Even after playing one of the many multitudes of varied maps and gametypes - which will keep you busy and entertained dozens of play-throughs each, you will inevitably run into something new and unexpected that will give you cause for hiding in a well-lit corner to reload, rethink, and take on the masses of walkers (and some sprinters) yet again, even while bleeding profusely, or slowly losing consciousness to infection, hoping - wishing - you find the necessary medication somewhere along your travels just in time before turning into one of those... things.   The developers in my mind have literally given the PC-gaming community a gift... by both making this game, while also making it free for us all to enjoy together. Masterfully crafted and downright scary, forcing one to be quick-thinking and quick on their feet, using both teamwork and individual contribution to the misson's goals, this free stand-alone zombie survival mod, that took 7 YEARS to create is worth every second, and every penny... if pennies were involved.  Try. This. Out. Highly recommended!

Before I begin, I must tell you all that No More Room in Hell can be abbreviated to nmrih. It is also easier to pronounce the two syllables Nim-Reh rather than the entire game title. My Experience : Nmrih was one of the most adrenaline rushing zombie game I could play for free on steam (granted you have some form of Source Engine SDK files installed already). The concept of having limited ammo and the introduction of teamwork was new and exciting. Though it was very hard to get used to the game at first, a few rounds of the game should help you ease into the playstyle. This isn't a shoot-em-up zombie survival game. This is a holding-onto-dear-life sort of gameplay. Guns and weapons are hard to scavenge, and the zombies can easily swarm the whole team, even though 80% of the zombies can only limp. The other 20% are runners, they run like marathon runners and you do not want to be near them unless you have a surefire shot with a gun or hit with a melee weapon on its head. I don't want to spoil the gameplay too much, so the rest of the game features can be yours to discover. Pros: -Plenty of maps and custom maps -Has survival mode and objective mode -FREE (if you have the source files) -Great co-op game -Still in development Cons: -Still in development (I repeated this because when a game is in development, it has things to be worked on, but it also means that the game's dev team isn't dead) -Hitboxes can be pretty weird (when the zombies change directions, their heads jerk too fast for the player to catch up with) -Doesn't give me free Cake for my birthday  That is the overall review of the game, I would highly recommend you get this game, so click That Green Button below to download now! Have fun surviving...

No More Room In Hell reminds me of those games where players progress through waves.For example,mobile game called Dead Trigger (it's in IOS and Android).an arcade-styled multiplayer where it test mostly teamwork and the wits of players in overcoming the waves of zombies.weapons and supplies are scattered throughout the map and large hordes of zombies to make things challenging  enough of descriptions,lets focus on the pros and cons of this game. the graphics of this game is good,detailed,and realistic,worth your time & patience to download it.no cons whatsoever (to me,of course)  But for the gameplay... it's dull,to be honest,dull.. there is no variety,it's all just walkers in large groups,and a few of them could sprint,not the zombie's that are just spawned could sprint,it's the players that are 'turned' could sprint.... there's no zombies that are based on their difficulty,which makes the game really lame... the AI movements are hilarious,they're so slow,even a snail could overrun them.i laughed so hard when i first played this game.. the character's movements is really stiff,kinda of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off at certain points.lastly,the HUD isn't complete.who needs to check their character's health by pressing 'R' anyway?  if the gameplay is improved,i'm sure most gamers would appreciate it,and it won't be so repetitive   Overall,good game,but players have to tolerate with it for now.i'll rate it 6/10,mostly on graphics. gameplay? not so much

No More Room in Hell: It's a shooter, multi-player based zombie apocalyptic survival game. There's 2 gamemodes which features in this game, objective based mission & survival. There are numerous maps as well as servers to play on. It allows you to pick up melee weapons, bullets, guns, medical supplies, etc.   Pros: -It's free! (although it's not the best game out there but one of the funnest games to play with your mates) -Plenty of people still play this games! -Easy to adjust into the gameplay mechanics. -Learn teamwork (or maybe not if you find the right people to play with :P)  -Simple gameplay yet interesting, did I forget to mention there's not much hackers here?  Cons: -Although it's free there are some glitchy zombies, it's not as bad as DAYZ zombies. -It can get frustrating sometimes when it comes to finding a game where everyone is playing (you'll spectate until the person dies or reach a check point then you can start to play. which it's kind of like FOREVER!!!)  Overall it's a good game, but hey it's free!! you can't really expect it to be 'perfectly polish' game... Hope this review helps :)

Saw a zombie wearing a shirt that says 'Hug me, I'm a vegan' 11/10 Would play again!  Anyways, here's my review. At frst glance the whole interface seems very confusing, but believe me... After a few hours you begin to realise the great potential this game has. Over the years, shooting zombies became mainstream. I mean really? You pick up a gun and fight through the horde on your own. This game manages to achieve something different. It's extremely unsettling and disturbing in a strange and unique way. I've been lanning this with my brother lately, and halfway through the missions you start getting a very strange feeling. It draws you in so well that you end up feeling like it really is a situation of life or death. Also, the maps are extremely difficult to clear, and once you get through one objective map, it feels GREAT! The sense of achievement is absolutely overwhelming and the joy of escaping with someone you know is brilliant! Beating a map will not only require practice and skill, but cooperation too. This is probably what stands out the most in NMRIH. You can go on and about grabbing all the weapons etc but believe me, you won't make it out alive on your own. It's about time we stop mindlessly gunning through hordes and use tactics as well as teamwork to progress through a game.  Thanks to the developers for creating a masterpiece.

I was seriously confused the entire time I played the game.  The killing mechanics were great, and the short time I played I had fun messing around. The game is fun. Its grimy, its bloody, its team defense based. It has guns and barely any ammo for them, so its really tense with a gun. The melee is seriously overkill in terms of joy. You could reskin the zombies with something cute and kawaii and it would still be fun to hack away at it.  But until I get some more friends into a private lobby I'd pass if I were you. Playing solo, or online public, didnt really teach me anything except how to tell people how many bullets I have left. Also, I doubt anyone has a system as lowend as mine anymore, but this game wouldnt run constant 30fps with shadows on. If you have the nvidia shadow issue with source engine games, its going to be ten times worse with this one because for some reason the shadows seem to extend across the limbs of enemies, making the game nearly unplayable without running 'r_shadows_gamecontrol 0'

Recommended!!!!!!  I enjoyed every moment in this game. Has a very realistic and creepy atmosphere. Unlike most zombie games which involve running in the open screaming and shooting with millions of bullets, this game requires teamwork, strategy and an open mind.   The undead in this game make each lone player seem underpowered as they can surround you and make you helpless. Zombies come in massive hordes and are difficult to kill unless you aim for the head. But as a team, you are more likely to survive a horde of the undead.  Ammo and bullet weapons are scarce but not to the point of never finding them. Each weapon has its own unique and very nice texture and model. And to make the survival expierence even more fun and difficult each weapons has its own size and weight. So you have to watch your inventory space.  Overall, this game is great for teamplayers, zombie killers, and people who want to have a fun time with friends (or enemies) And best of all, theres no pay to win.

No More Room in Hell  is a cooperatvie zombie survival game that makes you tense and makes sure you don't get too confident.    NMRiH  is also very slow-paced. Guns aren't abundant, and you might not even find a very good gun. Ammo is also incredibly scarce, and when you do find ammo, it's usually for a different gun than the one you have.  Healing/medical items are also very scarce, which is a huge problem when your character is bleeding/infected.  Zombies are mostly slow, but they're quite resilient and won't go down unless you attack their head. On top of that, only certain melee weapons are capable of one shot kills. So much as a single zombie can be threatening sometimes.  As I mentioned earlier, it's possible for your character to become infected; this sometimes happens when a zombie grabs you. When your character becomes infected, the infection will gradually worsen until it kills you. The infection can be held off by consuming pills; but doing so only buys you some extra time, and the infection will eventually come back. And don't forget what I said earlier about medical items being scarce.  The worst part about dying from infection (or just getting killed by a zombie while you're infected), is that your character will then turn into a zombie that is stronger, faster, and more aggressive than the standard zombies. This isn't really your problem (other than the part where you die), but your teammates will have to deal with zombified you (and like I said, zombie you is more dangerous than a normal zombie). If you don't want to turn (or don't want a friend to turn) and nobody has any pills, zombification can be prevented if an infected player is killed by another player. Speaking of which, friendly fire only applies to infected players by default; so if somebody says they're not infected but you think they're lying, you can just swing at them with your melee weapon and see if they take damage (I don't really recommend this, since some servers have friendly fire on at all times).  There are two main gamemodes: survival and objective. Survival maps require you to maintain control of certain areas of the map, with supplies being airdropped to you occasionaly so that you have a fighting chance. Objective maps are kind of like left 4 dead; get from the start of the map to the end with the occasional objective showing up that you have to complete to progress.  And something about it makes it so much  fun.  A crowd of zombies is difficult enogh that clearing a hallway of just 5 or 6 zombies almost feels like an accomplishment by itself. The difficulty makes completing a map really  feel  like escaping. You get more of a 'yeah, it's finally over!' feeling than a 'screw that map' feeling (unless the map sucks, but that's the map's fault).   TL;DR   NMRiH  is slow and difficult, but in a good way that makes everything strangely satisfying. You just gotta be patient.  Also, it's not that bad of a thing to kill a teammate that's hoarding everything.

Very gritty and realistic in terms of Z-appocolypse scenarios. This aint no Dead Rising, Dead Island or Left 4 Dead, kiddies, it is like George Romero with a slight twist. This time, you aim for the head ONLY (Anywhere else, you're wasting ammo) and be careful with various guns like automatics (Which are all sub-machine guns) and 'nades (Which includes, C4, molotovs, frags and dynamite). Know the ammo for your guns as you cannot pick up any random ammo box and it somehow turns into the right caliber or ammo type, the human vultures (Which are likely to be kids or trolls) always do this by picking up everything and filling up their inventory.  Speaking of the inventory system, it's really well made as it is limited by the size of the item. This really lets you look at your priorities as you don't have some magical way to store ALL your weapons and supplies on your person like in any other game. Ammo is also quite limited and is almost always jsut a luxury depending on the server (There are some servers with infinite ammo), map, and player's skill, so a good tip is to get a melee weapon of some kind, I prefer something with a long handle if you can find it like a sledge or fire axe and time your strikes right. So, don't just get guns because if you run out of ammo, you're screwed in more ways than one as the Zeds close in to horrificly rip you to shreds. BTW the only gun you can successfully kill zombies with a melee strike is one with a bayonett (I don't remember the name of the gun) and it's not a custom attachment. Also, protip, if youre infected and still fighting, I prefer you do the sensible thing (after actually telling everyone) and save the last bullet for yourself cuz, first timers get a cheevo.  Weapons have had a nice attention to detail as you actually need specific calibers, like the Ruger needs .22 LR and the m16 (Which has been permenately set to semi auto in this game) needs 5.56 ammunition. This also throws in unconventional weapons like the very tools you carry as you do missions, you could try to brain a zombie with your flashlight or welder. Watch out for fire weapons and molotovs as well as fire could turn all walking zombies into burning runners until they literally burn out so either run for your life or actually shoot bullets to finish it off. The operation and kick of each gun shows the devs really did their homework and probably made a few trips to a shooting range. The revolvers, after each shot, you can see the player model's thumb pull the hammer back. The shotgun's reload animation is nice as well as the player adds one more shot into the chamber making that one extra shot a bit more of a difference between life and death. The ammo hud is also a good attention to detail as it would fade away until you hold the reload button (R) to take a look at the ammo you have left as your character calls out how much he has left telling the other players to support you when they can.  Survival in general is a huge thing to look at. For example, if you're attacked by a zed there's more or less a 50/50 chance you are bitten which is garunteed to infect you even more when grabbed (so push them off with V to keep you from getting any more damage). As the infection spreads through your body, veiny paterns appear on your screen and your sight starts to darken. So your options are to either ask to be put down, find some phalanx, shooting yourself, or simply die while fighting the zeds off (Looking at other reviews, you'll see stories of people just being d**ks and not telling anyone so they can turn and just ruin lives). I highly recommend playing this with friends than strangers due to trust and communication issues that will plague public online games. If in a team, KEEP TOGETHER and dont lag behind, as in any zombie appocalypse scenarios (as shown in movies) Survivors have a better chance to survive with more people in their group. Adding to that, watch each other's back as you could be attacked from behind out of nowhere, especially in objective game modes (Survival game modes depend on how well you know the map and the layout of the map istelf).   Now onto the real stars, other than your fellow survivors, the zombies. The devs really did well with the walking corpses adding not only male and female zombies, but children and runners as well. Being surrounded by them makes the atmosphere pretty intense if you're on the run in objective mode or fiercely defending an objective in Survival mode. The children zombies are a bit of a pain to kill, not just that you're killing something that was just a sweet and innocent child in a previous life, but they are shorter and would force you to try to aim down. Runners are a bit of a problem but not as much as the children in my opinion, you just have to react fast and blast them on the face with your shotgun or pistol or let your buddies take them down. The zombie moans you hear are also a nice small detail the devs pay attention to as they have varying pitches and 'voice' like a child zombie's would be higher pitch and a bit more raspy same for a zombie woman's. It's also satisfying to see a Zed's head pop when you land a solid headshot.  I HIGHLY recommend this to anyone looking for a more genuine zombie game as this makes you feel like you're in a zombie movie struggling to survive with other survivors.
BEST F2P ZOMBIE GAME IN THE WORLD

It's like a free version of left 4 dead, nuff said. Still im gonna say more. The game may be free but unlike other free to plays like it it doesnt lack in content. It's a fun team based game where the character you play has very little chance of surviving. One thing that I find really interesting is the fact that your character can become infected and turn into a zombie (you don't get to control the zombie) which will do a ton of disorientating damage to your old team. The game never lacks in excitement either, if i take you on a little trip down memory lane you might understand better. One of the first times i played the game i was with a friend, and we were clueless. To spare you the boring details i will just say this, the story ends with a blowtorch, a sewer, a phonebooth, and lots of gernades. So in fear of dragging this already long review out to be even longer I will simply end it with the good ol' 'worth the buy, or free download I should say, lots of fun.'

This game is one of the scariest, most realistic zombie-survival games I've ever played in my life, this game has given me the most horrifying and fun experience, I've never felt so hopeless and terrified in any game before. You can play alone but it's more fun playing with other players. This game is very difficult, as in really really difficult, because once you're infected, you'll eventually die and become a zombie.   There are survival maps and objective maps in the game, survival maps is where you survive wave after wave of zombies, and objective maps is where you will have to complete set of objectives until you get to the end and successfully escape the zombie infested map. Most of the time you'll be using melee weapons to defend yourself since guns and ammo are scarce, along with other resources such as medkits and bandages for when you're injured, you'll truly succumb to fear in this game and you'll be fighting for your life to survive. :)

I don't write reviews often, but I gotta say this game is one of the best games around for those looking for zombie action. Here are both pros and cons of the game:  Pros: - Unique Combat (Gunplay and melee combat is unique compared to other games, being slower, heavier and more deliberate) - Objective based gameplay (As opposed to being put in a world to roam around with no clear objective, gameplay is linear with a clear objective and goal) - Well designed maps (Each map is unique with its own gimmick, be it a sewer level or using trains) - Team based gameplay (Adds to the sense of realism, in that in a zombie apocalypse you can't survive on your own) - Great atmosphere (All the maps feel eerie, zombies are still creepy, the possibility of infection keeps you on edge) - Damage Spread (Reduces consisteny of attacks, so not every power attack will be a one hit kill, keeps you on your toes) - Non-artifical scarcity (Rather than just artifical scarcity, weapons are where you expect them but not plentiful. Dead survivors may have a pistol, gun shops have a large display of rifles, rust belt cabins have a large containment of revolvers and shotguns etc.) - Maximum accessibility (Minimum PC requirements, game is free, allows anyone to pick it up)  This in turn makes a really unique zombie shooter game, which seems fairly simple and easy, given the shuffling nature of most zombies, but when times least expect it can become one of the hardest games around!  Cons: - Game relies heavily on communication (Lack of friends to talk with can seriously impede your chances of survival) - Scarcity is not proportional to number of players (When there is a full server, it can often lead to situations where only a few survivors have weapons and the rest are with melee) - Barricading isn't useful (Zombies won't be detered around to another spot, and you cannot use melee weapons to poke through the slits. The only way to hurt other zombies is to destroy the barricades themselves) - The wave based survival mode isn't the most fun (Maps aren't balanced in terms of weapons, with some maps being much easier than others. The designated safe zones are arbitrary, survivors can't choose where they stage their HQ). - A common plugin in servers is infinite ammo which totally detracts from the game itself - Maps are sometimes too linear. Maps should have 2/3 ways of moving towards a goal rather than through one corridor which they must fight through  Overall, this is one of my favourite games around, and given that it is free, it really allows anyone to pick it up!  A unique game that no other game quite offers. 8/10
